content:
ry 18, 2015
												I got my first taste of Fallout with Fallout 3, and I immediately fell in love. I couldn't think of a better game out there. And then Fallout New Vegas came along. And I'll be honest, I was not a fan. Not in the least. First glance was a desolate land that had more punishing combat and a bizarre ammo system. Fast forward a couple months and I decide to give it another go. For some reason this second foray really opened my eyes and I had a blast with the changed up combat that made you think, and the ammo system that gave you more flexability. And once I started playing I discovered something even more miraculous: the writing. Fallout New Vegas had a more believable environment, better characters, better writing. It simply felt more thought out. And looking into its development I discovered that it had some of the creators of the original Fallouts working on it. So I had to give the originals a try.So I started with Fallout 1, of course. I bought the pack off of steam and installed it with a gusto. Finally the 5 minute process ended and I delightfully booted up the game, only to have a brilliant rainbow engulf the screen. Great. So I do some quick interneting and download the hi-res pack for Fallout 1 and Killap's Restoration Pack for Fallout 2 in order to plan ahead. Fallout 1 started, and I hit the ground running. My first isometric RPG! Woo-hoo! I immediately fell flat on my face, being killed by rats. I learned my first Fallout lesson: It's okay to run. So after hours of such trial and error I finally completed my game of Fallout 1, and was eager to continue the adventure in Fallout 2.If you have made it this far, good lord. On to Fallout 2.Fallout 2, to put it mildly, blew me away. Though the first level was obnoxious as hell. That Temple deserves to burn. Regardless, I pushed forward and entered the world proper. And it was glorious. Everything good from Fallout 1, Fallout 2 has. And then it expands on those. And THEN adds even more. I could do anything here. The world was truely my playground. I could, and did, do anything I wanted. The combat is incredibly punishing, forcing you to make some truely tactical decisions, however it just makes every win that much more satisfying. The dialogue is witty, dark, a tad campy at times, and heartbreaking. The depths of depravity that is portrayed is mindboggling in the modern game sphere. GTA has nothing on this. Additionally I simply love the Enclave. Probably shouldn't, but I do. I really didn't do this game justice at all, did I? When it came down to it I didn't know what to say.Buy this, install it, download the Restoration Pack, install that, play the game, never stop.

content:
r 22, 2015
												This is it.  This is the game the cemented the Fallout universe and is considered by many the pinnacle of the series until New Vegas.  This is the game the truly cements the core story of the franchise and takes the seeds planted in FO1 and grows them to fruitiion.  In that process, they helped open up countless routes for storylines for the rest of the series.Some folks complain that now a game like this feels dated.  I would do my best to compel to you put aside that sort of metric when it comes to assessing the greatness of a game.  With some patience and thought ,which is so often taken out of today popular games, you can grasp hold of what seems at first glance, a copmlicated system for conveying your player character through the in-game universe.The routes you take, many encounters, and many other aspects of the game are so open, so huge, that you could play through many times and still find different things. There are so many hidden routes, items, quests, etc and so many ways to play the game it's impossible to describe them all here(smart, tech savvy character or a  brawler or a dimwit?  you can play them all and they all change the game)This game is a classic for a reason and is the gold standard by which other similar games should be judged.Buy it, play it, and understand where one of the greatest game franchises ever got much of it's spark.Do it now.

												A worthy successor to Fallout 1, and for those who loved the original they're in for a whole new experience.Few RPGs provide so deft a balance between the wandering monster-slaying and the NPC interaction phases of role-playing.Perhaps even more so than its predecessor, Fallout 2 contains dozens of subtle and more often not-so-subtle references to cult movies, television icons, and other aspects of popular culture.If you value character development, old-fashioned gameplay, and a good plot, this game delivers on all counts.

content:
15, 2016
												War. War never changes.The end of the world occurred pretty much as we had predicted. Too many humans, not enough space or resources to go around. The details are trivial and pointless, the reasons, as always, purely human ones.The earth was nearly wiped clean of life. A great cleansing, an atomic spark struck by human hands, quickly raged out of control. Spears of nuclear fire rained from the skies. Continents were swallowed in flames and fell beneath the boiling oceans. Humanity was almost extinguished, their spirits becoming part of the background radiation that blanketed the earth.A quiet darkness fell across the planet, lasting many years. Few survived the devastation. Some had been fortunate enough to reach safety, taking shelter in great underground vaults. When the great darkness passed, these vaults opened, and their inhabitants emerged to begin their lives again.One of the northern tribes claims they are descended from one such Vault. They hold that their founder and ancestor, one known as the "Vault Dweller," once saved the world from a great evil. According to their legend, this evil arose in the far south. It corrupted all it touched, twisting men inside, turning them into beasts. Only through the bravery of this Vault Dweller was the evil destroyed. But in so doing, he lost many of his friends and suffered greatly, sacrificing much of himself to save the world.When at last he returned to the home he had fought so hard to protect, he was cast out. Exiled. In confronting that which they feared, he had become something else in their eyes...and no longer their champion.Forsaken by his people, he strode into the wasteland. He traveled far to the north, until he came to the great canyons. There, he founded a small village, Arroyo, where he lived out the rest of his years. And so, for a generation since its founding, Arroyo has lived in peace, its canyons sheltering it from the outside world. It is home. Your home.But the scars left by the war have not yet healed. And the Earth has not forgotten.

content:
er 15, 2016
												Whew, this game. I could make a big frickin' list about the cool stuff here (plus killap's Restoration Project, which is a ♥♥♥♥in' awesome mod), but I am too lazy to do that. What I will say, though, is that you should definitely play Fallout before trying out Fallout 2 because of the story, obviously (if you don't care about story, I don't know what you're doing here), and also for the better introduction to the gameplay system and game that Fallout gives. Fallout 2 is harder, longer, and has way more quests and content, of course. I mean, damn, dude, in Fallout, you start with a gun, some ammo, stimpacks, a knife, fighting some silly weak rats. In Fallout 2, you're a tribal with nothing else other than a spear, fighting giant ants. It shouldn't be a big deal for players who are used to it, but I've seen people complaining about dying way too much at the beginning of Fallout 2 (and guess what, a lot of them never even played the first one!). I think I've played and finished this game more than enough to say that I loved it, and I still do, as I enjoy playing it from time to time, and try some different cool builds. I'm not an old school gamer, but I still feel a great compassion for this game, which I truly think is well-made. (Guess I'm not so lazy at all, seeing as I took the time to at least write a bit about this cool game.) Totally recommend it.

												I've spent a fair share of hours for this game, and I'll say they were all well spent.I'll admit, this game does require patience, but once you've figured out where that one object is or where that one person went, it makes it all worthwhile.You may have to look up a tutorial here and there, but that doesn't matter that much in the end. What matters is that YOU picked up the object, YOU found and talked to the person, YOU fought the final boss. Because the tutorial can't press the keys or control the mouse, only you can.Besides all the deep talk, fallout 2 offers a lot for players who liked fallout 1 or just like turn-based RPGs. There is a wide variety of quests,weapons,people and locations all for you(the player)to find and explore. The campaign isn't linear and gives you choices on how to handle different situations. What more do you want? Why are you still reading? Buy the game and go head-first into the wasteland of fallout 2!

content:
, 2014
												Fallout 2 in my opinion is the best in a series of games that include Fallout 3 and New Vegas. Nothing like going back old school days with this fantastic turned based RPG. The story telling in this game is unique, very often funny, and always engaging. You are free to be who you want to be in the wastelands of Fallout, want to be a prick that steals from everyone? Maybe you want to be the hero who saves the children instead of killing them? With the way karma works in this game your actions very much affect the way the world reacts to you and your party. Along with the choice to go where ever in the world, the skill system is just as open, you can spend your skill points however you like. I find myself making many characters just to try out different styles of play. You could be a sweet talking brawler, a thieving sharp shooter, or even a non-combatant that talks, repairs, or barters thier way to the end, the choices are truly up to you. If you do decide to buy this be sure to download Killaps unoffical patch and Killaps Restoration project, both have installers and make the game more incredible. Oh and by the way kids, stay off the jet, it's addictive!

												Okay this game is like Fallout 1 but stretched out with NEW features that the developers played around with. I was quite surprised how long the game was, maybe too long. I found out that I only did 75% of the game before finishing it. That is huge when I have played the game for nearly 20 hrs. BUT that car has some of the worse bugs in video game history, you can be an unlucky player like I did and lost the car randomly, never to ever see it again. There is no way to track where your car is situated and yea if you lose track of it or if the lost car bug happens to you, that's it no more car for you. You cant get it back nor can you get another one. Also in this game you can play your character even AFTER you finish the game to pick up the quests you missed etc. It is a good game but a very long and buggy game too. Still definately worth it, but you must stick with it for the long haul. :)

content:
6, 2013
												I'd rather confidenly say this is the best Fallout game in the series so far. All of them have great atmosphere and mood, but they also have their fair share of stupid mistakes or just plain lack of certain qualities. Fallout 2 eludes most of the failings of its predecessor and its successors and stands strong on its own as well.It provides enough variety and character to feel full and alive, while staying true to the mood and maintaining the bar of quality at a reasonable level. Just as importantly, it maintains a very decent level of reactivity and non-linearity, and offers maybe not perfect but seriously flexible mechanics. It also introduces the best plot twist of the whole series. So all in all, I'd call it the purest and the most successful execution of the Fallout concept so far. Even though I would love it to have more of the desperate and mysterious mood of the very beginning of Fallout 1, the vast pretty enviroments of Fallout 3 and the tasteful characterization of New Vegas.

, 2016
Product received for free
												At the time of this review, this game is literally old enough to vote in the United States. And yet no other game has made me so deliriously happy to finally get my hands on a gun.Pros:-Top-notch dialogue and writing in general-Well-designed strategic combat-Major emphasis on roleplay and many ways to accomplish any given goal-Difficulty level that reinforces the harshness of the setting without being too hardcore-I am attended by a fat, balding tuna can merchant who karate chops scorpions for me-60 fpsCons:-Hope you like brown and beige-Occasional b.s. random encounter, like spawning in the middle of a scorpion nest-There are two very obvious god stats: Agility for combat (how often you can attack and how far you can move), and Intelligence for everything else (how many skill points you get when you level up, the base value for the highly useful First Aid skill, and for some inane reason how persuasive you are in dialogue, making Charisma close to useless).

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 21, 2014
												The masterpiece of all rpgs, Fallout 2 yet its practicly a son of wasteland, this game is worth the weight, worth getting rid of your nagging girlfriend/wife and worth quitting that business monkey job, you don't need any of that anyway! all you need is a fresh nuka-cola and some fallout 2. Now in a few weeks is mah birthdays with planning to buy wasteland 2 I decide to write my personal expierence and opinon on this game.Why you ask? I will tell you my experience.Here you are born in a tribal village in the wasteland of america,  your home where your ancestor known as the vault dweller of V13 was exiled from his overseer due to the fear of spreading diseases and radiation inside the vault towards the pure dwellers, your ancestor did nothing wrong but saved his people from being forced out of the vault into the cruel wasteland due to a dying water supply and being raided by monsterous mutants of the Master's army, he walked north and north to find a tribal village on the wasteland... in present time, you discover your home village is dying.. brahmin are dying, children sick with diseases. everything was starting to fall apart slowly, but you the decendant of the v13 dweller have been chosen by the village's elder to go out the wasteland explored by your ancestor to find the mighty G.E.C.K to fix all this hell happening.. and that is where your journey begins.Now with some quick tips before you first time play this game:I reccomend reading this guide to help you get started playing, trust me its worth to read than being torn to shreds by a small Enclave patrol or getting shotgunned in the face when you try to fight with melee in a random encounter. small spoilers because the guide also brings up the details with all the quests available in this gamehttp://fallout.wikia.com/wiki/The_Nearly_Ultimate_Fallout_2_Guide#Character_designDon't ragequit over getting wrecked by a bunch of geckos or radscorpians, the more you play the game, the better. Okay so now onto the Gameplay, its very Turnbased but its rewarding seeing the animations of someones torso being blown to bits by shotguns and mini-guns, even melting him like a witch with a plasma gun is entertaining too, of course you can also be blown to bits by anyone. there isn't open world exploration like you get in fallout 3 because outside of towns/other places will bring a large map with a green dot (you) click around and you move around, when you want to travel to another location for the side/main quests  you will often have random encounters such as radscorps, walking into a middle of a firefight between caravans and bandits, there are peaceful encounters like the caravans who will trade with you for caps (aka money) of course the small downside with trading is your karma status effects the caravans, some of them will refuse to trade with you either becuase you are known as a evil fat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ villlain  or a goodie white knight of the wasteland it mainly depends on  locations that you are nearby like the cities, small hint there are easter egg encounters too!You can also choose to do what ever you want. Killing before asking/chatting, turning the tables of the side quest (i.e giving the brahmin you were meant to guard to the twins when you trick your dumb tribal friend into running away) you can't slaughter the villagers in your home cus otherwise the game will be over insta.There are also Companions that you can take with you on your travels, based on my experience I will give you the details of the companions I had with me.Vic This man may be your second/first companion you can bring along, he's good for ranged weapons, be sure to collect his rifle at his shack in the first town you go to, but he's often slow and bad for melee combat. Lenny A ghoul, he's not great with combat and carrys a knife with him but he is a decent doctor, have him as your field medic and sort. Also he cannot run.Marcus this guy has a talking head voice acted too, but if you want this big hulk with you, its best you either take his mini-gun away and give him a plasma rifle, or have him as your only companion because he will freaking kill every single thing in his line of fire no matter who's infront when you're in combat, his mini-gun often has a unaccurate shot hitting mutiple targets in a burst of fire which means he can instantly kill you or his fellow companion by accident. K9 this cyber dog is simliar to the famous dog-meat but he can talk and is cool, you can find him inside a lab at the navvarro Enclave base, its best you get in there with the highwayman car otherwise you will have a pain in the ♥♥♥ experience getting killed by enclave patrols in 1 turn every time. Goris this DEATHCLAW is quite a badass, except he can only fight with his claws in melee so he can sometimes get in your line of fire including marcus's and his animation with his jedi cloak gets repeative. The story also has multiple endings on every town and faction you have met along in your travels, your actions towards them will bring them a future, for example if you slaughter the slavers at the Den and free the slaves, the town will flourish and sort, and if you screw up modac its gonna die because you made a mistake on your decision. Immersion on this game regardless of the graphics is really great too, you're gonna get tempted to kill somebody because of what-he-said about those poor ghouls or maybe even insulting you. This is not some fallout 3 where enclaves gets killed by revolvers, or deathclaws getting killed in 3 seconds or children being immune to gunshots Oh yeah you can kill kids in this game if you're a heartless monster :3  this is fallout 2 friend. -fun turnbased gameplay-immersive storyline-able to do what you want that can effect karma or faction/town reputation including the ending of the faction and town.

content:
14, 2016
												I played this after i went through Fallout 4 to see if it was as good as i remember it to be, and i was not disappointed. This is one billion times better than fallout 4 when it comes to the sheer feel of it all, Everything just works. It's such a perfect game, with an immensely rewarding and equally punishing combat system. The calculations of the hit percentage, the gameplay itself, the old graphics, the isometric viewpoint. Everything .. JUST ... WORKS. I haven't gone through the entire game since i am quite the slow player, but believe me, so far this has surpassed fallout 4 in every way imaginable. Plus i have after all played the game before, 17 years ago. as for the gameplay, let me give you a story:Once upon a time there was a gunfight between 7 golden geckoes and a lone tribes-man who just left his companion because he kept blocking passages infront of doors so that the tribes-man would have to save and reload until the companion rearranged his position. So, as the - never again - "lone" tribes-man (conveniently named with the most ineligible, and unsuiting name since the dawn of time) stood infront of the golden geckoes he had an epiphany that this would not end in an orderly fashion (he also did inconveniently forget to save the game since he is, and was a complete moron). He fought until there was all but one golden gecko left, with 7HP and an arm with a golden shine to it on the ground. The tribes-man with a peculiar name raised his one-shot gun as far as his ripped up arms could bear, with the 5 remaining Action-points - the fairly girthy built man had left - He pulled the trigger costing him 3 action points. The gun gasped for air as the bullet traveled through the 50cm long, rifled barrel. The bullet caught a spin and flew through the air (just like the keys on a keyboard when a companion decides to block a passage), it got near the golden gecko and flew straight past, because the tribes-man was a retard and didn't for one second think to move closer with the two actionpoints he had left in him. It was now the gecko's turn and the tribes-man died horribly in one move. Moral of the story: "you die in-game if you make a mistake in a crucial moment, and you die IRL when you haven't saved for 2 hours".10/10, childhood memories comes flooding back from me pulling my hair in dispair.sincerely, Nomad

content:
, 2016
												Fallout 2 is a perfect sequel to the best original RPG of its time, Fallout.Fallout 2 features an open-world with a S.P.E.C.I.A.L skill system like in the previous game with a larger map and even more locations to discover than the original.In this installment, you are the descendant of the main character from Fallout 1, and it is your job to bring the legendary G.E.C.K to your village of Arroyo. During the journey to save Arroyo, you run across a sprawl of interesting characters, from shady dealers to trusting companions. Who will you side with? What will be your playstyle? All of this is important in Fallout 2.Fallout 2 introduces a new villianous organization, The Enclave. They are the remnants of the pre-war government, and their goal is to control the Wastes and minipulate it, by elimating all mutants and "in-perfect" beings, inclusong yourself.The Enclave soon discovers you and Arroyo, which leads to grave consequences...So the choice is yours. Fallout 2 is possibly my favorite, if not one of my favorite Fallout games to date. Play this, no regretti THIS speghetti.9.5/10 Starfish

content:
er 14, 2013
												I loved videogames as a kid and my favorites were the action and rpg games where I played the hero with the sword slaying my enemies.  Naturally I was pumped as I put my max strength character into this world, heroically exterminating giant ants with my spear.  And after that earned me the title of 'Chosen One' nothing could stop me.  So weapon in hand I search for injustice in the closest town and find a slavers guild.  There is no room for this evil in my world!  I charge right through the front door and skewer the boss twice with my trusty spear of justice...   at which point six heavily armored guards blast my head and arms off with submachine guns, as my 11 year old eyes stare in shock at my blood sputtering corpse on the floor.  I would forever remember this day as when I TRULY understood why guns are better than swords.Fallout 1 and 2 are both artifacts from a time when there was no mainstream gaming.  Big companies all made indie games, and this is a result when that money isn't restricted by demographics and overprotective mother influenced censorship.  No indie game can match the beauty that comes from collaboration and detail this game has in both its gameplay and art.For truly shocking me into the reality of a world that no HD game has done since, Fallout 2 gets 10/10.

content:
y 25
												So, all I have to say is that I'm quite glad I played the first two Fallout games as they are great! While 3 and New Vegas still are my favorite games in the franchise, the first two Fallout games are still amazing and definitely have withstood the test of time.I think the one thing I love the most is that the game is demanding, making you think out each action carefully, which I like, it also is fair with its difficulty.  Plus, it requires you to really think about how you build your character. I at first mistakenly built my character in the game with a gun-centric build focused around accuracy with guns, not realizing the first quest, you didn't get any guns and had to use a spear. Luckily, I quickly realized my error and made a similar character with the build to make it through the Temple of Trials without dying at all. (Thank goodness for those Healing Powders...) It's really good to see a game that isn't dumbed down too much.I love the soundtrack in this game as well.  The gloomy music is perfect with the atmosphere.Gameplay is very nice, too. Quite fun. Especially with the whole D&D style of gameplay.If I had to list any problems with the game... One, my save files keep getting corrupted for some reason... >:( and two is that the game doesn't always seem to want to work on my laptop, which has NO trouble running Fallout 3 or New Vegas.

content:
17, 2016
A Better RPG than Fallout 4Bleeding from several wounds, I thrust my spear once more toward my enemy, this time connecting, finally. I'm poisoned, bleary eyed and have six hitpoints remaining. I just survived the first dungeon with a charismatic character. I killed some Giant Ants. This is what Fallout was. A sprawling, tough RPG that actually required some amount of planning toward your character and your decisions. Even to this day the dialogue is great and the story gripping yet allows a sense of freedom. If you want a fighting character you better make a fighting character. When I played Fallout 4 I made an incredibly charismatic, intelligent character with poor stats in fighting. I still managed to kill everything. In Fallout 2 I barely survived the first dungeon, getting mauled by Lesser Scorpions and Giant Ants, all because I wanted my character to be a talker, not a fighter. Obviously it's aged; three mousepointers need to be alternated between; combat, movement and interaction. There's a panel that brings up skills and not everything is made immediately clear. But if those main 'problems' with the game don't scare you away then this is a great game. It's worth a try, even if just to see how Fallout was and to experience a true gaming classic; one that will remain for countless years as a great game in the history of gaming. jmcone's Personal Rating: Highly Recommended

												I will reccomend this game as the time that I have been able to play it (not anymore) was amazing. But, I will have to give you some adviceDO NOT RELY ON THE STEAM CLOUD, THE SAVES WILL NOT WORK!(I found this out the hard way)Just as you would have thought from me writing this, my saves will no longer work. I had put 39 hours into this game and then, one day my computer starts running into issues. Long story short I had to completly reset my HDD and reinstall windows. I thought I would still be able to play Fallout 2 as my saves have been uploaded onto the steam cloud. When I reinstalled the game, my saves came along with it, only for every save to give me this error upon attemping to load "The instruction at 004f11db referenced memory from 00000010 The memory could not be read from" I have looked up just about every single discussion about this error and nobody can find a way past it. I have posted about it on reddit, steam discussions and nma-fallout.com. It is unfixable and therefore I have wasted 39 hours of my life.Other than this big problem the game ran completly fine on my modern pc with no crashing, plus I really did love this game when I was able to play it.

content:
ry 21, 2016
												This is a case of learning from past mistakes and implementing fixes that are fun and fair. The improvements in gameplay are spectacular and make this a must own for nearly any gamer, both new and old. Then the beautiful mixture of story and world building. One of the best old school RPG's I've played.So like I said in my Fallout review this game fixes nearly every gameplay issue I had from the first one. The VATS hit calculations seem far more logical and correct, though it suffers a few times in a playthrough. I did not feel like rage quitting because of it at any point like the original did so many times. Thank you for this improvement.Criticals, another point from my Fallout review, vastly improved. So now enemies will actually do damage to you throughout the game, and criticals won't drain you in a single shot usually. Once again I found the new system of critcals to be fair and appropriate. So the story takes a step backward but then takes two more forward. The stepbackward is the depth of the NPC's. That has left, unfortunately, but has been replaced with greater variety. These enhance the world quite a bit, while giving you a little wish that some NPC's were used a little more. It's a better trade off in the end, because not only does it build story within The Chosen One's life but it also creates world depth. So this could go either way depending on your preference.Add onto all of this more weapons and items. Then a Highwayman to boot. This is a monumental increase in gameplay making this a fun game and a great story.

content:
y 9, 2012
												Perhaps my favorite RPG ever...perhaps. The stat system offers unparalleled variety. This might be the only RPG, for example, where having a low Intelligence actually changes the way your character talks and how NPCs respond (you haven't truly played until you've tried a character with a level 1 INT and watched him bumble about like a cartoon Neanderthal). Also, the game is huge and, best of all, you can do all the things that RPGs usually shy away from: go on a mass child killing spree, get addicted to speed, become a gay porn star (provided your "endurance" score is high enough, of course), contract venereal diseases, become a pimp or a slave trader. What's not to love? Plus, everything's given a sort of "Gee Whiz!," "Leave it to Beaver" sheen so the contrast between the main character's wide eyed naiveté and the often terrible stuff he's duped into doing (often with the best intentions) is always amusing and can provide a good deal of comedy (depending on how you play).

												Does Fallout 2 hold up in 2016? as a game that is 18 years old it holds up very well. The story is fantastic, the rpg elements are amazing, and the exploration is beautiful. I suggest buying this game if you have 10 dollars sitting around. When I booted up the game, I was greeted to a Native American inspired level, and I was not interested but as the game progressed I realized there is a lot more to it. I recommend going straight to san fran from the beginning, meeting the BOS then going camp navarro, then you can get the enclave power armor, and you might level up a couple times. I love fallout 4, 3, and new vegas and I love fallout 2, people say dont buy this game if you like the latest fallout games, but to hell with that, this game is amazing and deep with storytelling, please buy this game, it is worth every dime.

content:
4, 2015
												Hoo boy. I have mixed feelings on this one.Fallout 2 is more or less the same as Fallout in terms of gameplay, but with improvements, which is certainly a plus. There is one minor gameplay quibble I have, and that's that they slightly nerfed the Turbo Plasma Rifle for no good reason. Why, besides trying to make the Pulse Rifle seem better by comparison? That seems like the completely wrong way to go about it, making and trying to balance new content by changing the old. It was fine! On the subject of equipment changes, they also reduced the weight of the Power Armor by about half with no explanation. I'd accept that if you at least acknowledged it, but now it just seems kind of silly. Just one offhand remark about removing unnecessary systems in there! THAT'S IT!Anyway, the story issue is a bit more complex. The focus in Fallout 2, I've noticed, is more based on the moment-to-moment or area-to-area experience, rather than Fallout 1's cohesive whole. As a result, the whole thing seems more scattered, muddier, and overall less entertaining and less absorbing, as they'll do anything to make sure that you're never not entertained, while Fallout made sure that there was a single, easy-to-follow narrative, leading to a better and more consistent atmosphere.One other really annoying thing: the game takes forever to get going, especially for gun-oriented characters. The Temple of Trials and the majority of Klamath have nothing but scorn for your desire to find a single ranged weapon that doesn't have a 1-bullet clip, and even then you're still on shaky ground until maybe the Den. For a while, I even tried to just play a hand-to-hand character for this game simply because the beginning is so stupidly unhelpful! In contrast, take a look at Fallout 1's beginning. You're kicked out the door. You have a gun, a knife, and ammo to spare (and a definite and straightforward goal). Boom. All playstyles are go. Even with the gameplay sorting itself out, the whole Fallout 2 package doesn't really get engaging until Gecko. After that, though, it really does pick up steam, and by the Enclave you realize that just now you're getting the experience and thrills that Fallout 1 was delivering from square one. (I should probably mention that eventually I was so desperate for some fun way forward that I looked up Per Jorner's excellent guide. That was what truly rekindled my interest, and I urge everyone to check it out. It contains levels of love and research of and for a game that I haven't seen since Everything You Wanted to Know About Headcrabs and More. Check that out too, actually.)Overall, I like Fallout 1 more. Fallout 2 is huge, much bigger than its predecessor, and has its share of wonderous delights (don't get me wrong on that), but more often than not for me they're hidden behind some sort of obtuse non-engaging..sloppiness? Design oversight? Overreaching? that the first game rarely if ever had. I guess I'd still recommend it -mostly for the story connectivity- but really, Fallout 1 is the better of the two, in my opinion.TL;DR I like Fallout 1 more, it seems to me that they got sloppy with this one. Too big to ignore, though.Also, some of the canonical and best endings are hidden behind lazy bugs? WHAT?EDIT: Just recently, I've been replaying the Fallout games in preparation for Fallout 2. When it came time for Fallout 2, I used Per Jorner's guide to speedrun through the thing in the course of a night. Playing through the entire thing once was enough for me.

content:
y 30, 2014
												After putting a couple hundred hours into Fallout: New Vegas, I decided to play the first three games. I started with Fallout. It was fun and gave some background information to common themes in the later games. I beat it in under 24 hours, if I hadn't wasted 3 hours remaking characters that could survive it would have been less. Then came Fallout 2. With the experience I had gained from Fallout I ran into Fallout 2 expecting a cakewalk. I was wrong. The wasteland had became an even harsher place. It took over 50 hours to beat this game and I loved every moment. Unlike in Fallout where I had ditched Ian late in the game to comtinue on, I found myself reloading ealier saves time after time when Lenny or Cassidy died. I ran all over the wasteland avoiding the Enclave and mutants searching for secret places and proper oppponents. I hope when I start Fallout 3 Soon that I can experience the same level of investment in a game.

												It's definitely harder to get into than Fallout 1, but in the end it's worth it. Whereas Fallout 1 drew me right in from the start, I had to force myself through the first couple hours of Fallout 2, but it was worth it. What you find is a game with everything that Fallout 1 did right, (the atmosphere, the characters, the immersion, the story) and added onto it with a bigger environment, more things to do, more items, and a generally longer and more diverse gaming experience. Highly recommended to anybody who can appreciate an older game.NOTE: If using windows 7, the colours will most likely look really distorted when you launch the game. This makes the game unplayable, but it can be easily 'fixed' by closing explorer.exe when you run the game.

content:
0, 2014
												Fallout 2 was a game pirated and given to me on a blank CD by a friend's little brother in high school. What I got out of the game has lasted me a lifetime. From it's familiar locales like New Reno and San Francisco, to it's gritty noir, Fallout 2 has it all.  You could even murder kids and get branded a Childkiller. Not your forte? You can go into the porn industry in New Reno! If you're any sort of fan of post-apocalytic scenarios or films in general, this is an assured staple for your library. Every few years (or new computer, I suppose), I would dig out my old burned copy and reinstall it to give it another playthrough. I happened upon a one-day sale wherein Fallout 1-3, New Vegas, and Tactics were all $2.49 apiece. Naturally, I ♥♥♥♥ with glee and promptly ordered. This game will entrance you, given a few hours of dedication. Just like Fallout 3, Fallout 2 begins with a catchy, old-timey tune; in this case, it's Louis Armstrong's "Kiss To Build A Dream On." Here's hoping this game sticks with you, too.

												Hello Fellow Wastelanders,I strongly suggest the purchase of Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game! It's a wonderful game, even though it's a little bit old and still uses a turn-based system. The game's storyline is amazing and it feeds into the future Fallout games. It also builds off of the original Fallout, but it doesn't make you feel clueless when you first start. It's a wonderful game, great storyline, great everything, that leads into a great series. I strongly recommend it if you are into the lore of the series! Definitely worth the money!-Kyle James

content:
ry 22, 2016
												CANNOT RECOMMEND ENOUGH! This and Fallout 1 are MUST OWNS! I recently purchased the 2 in a bundle and I seriously cannot put them down! I've been hooked on them for 2 weeks straight. Now I know if you're like me and not from the era of these types of games you need to be in the mood to play this type of top down, turn based system. But if you look up a quick guide like I did, I was used to the system and was having fun within the first 20 min of Fallout 1. And since FO2 is so similar, you can get straight into it. - The story of the games is 10/10, love them.- The worlds (especially Fallout 2) are sensational, I spoke to every NPC to soak in as much info as I could- The companions are cool but as always in these games, they're in the way a lot and they shoot you a fair bit (Much improved in fallout 2 since you can push them out of the way)- And the CHOICES! I now understand why all the other fans were dissapointed in FO3 and 4.. the choices and consequences here are exciting and rewarding.- FO2 = Best RPG i've ever playedThere is sooo much more to be said here but I need to get back to slaughtering slavers. I wish I could forget the two games just so I could experience them for the first time again!TL;DR: Best RPGS ever, world, story, choices 11/10. Buy buy buy

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
												(Post Fallout 1 Review) Fallout 2 continues 70-80 years after Fallout 1, playing as the ancestor of your previous character, the "Vault Dweller" or also called the "Chosen One". You are sent off into the wastes to help your tribe "Arroyo" and uncover the legacy The Vault Dweller left behind within California/Nevada and introducing a new grand threat who origins are from those whom governed before, the "ENCLAVE". Remnants of the United States.The core gameplay mechanics never really changed when transitioning between Fallout 1 and 2 (Isometric turned based combat). The most noticable differences is the amount of new perks, and the way you begin the game. Fallout 2 entices you to create a close-quarters heavy build, over Fallout 1's small guns since you are a tribal. This game also introduces a boatload of new companions (12-13), which smothers Fallout 1's four followers. Fallout 2 has plenty of new quests that all intertwine nicely together, as multiple factions and cities effect one another.Tons of Fallout cameos, pop-culture references, and tons of new content. Such a lovely addition to my Fallout experience! (Did one playthrough, with around 90% of the sidequests complete. Time clocked: Around 50 hours)

content:
ber 3, 2015
In The End, Why Not Just Hit Children In The Groin With A Sledgehammer - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]In the event that the world ever ends, be it zombie apocalypse, nuclear armageddon, or any other fun kind of catastrophe, I feel like humanity definitely will live on. We're a stubborn race of beings. Like cockroaches. We're everywhere, we just won't go away, and we seem to find a way to procreate everywhere.Out of every possible way that the human race could near extinction, I think being mostly annihilated by an atomic bomb or so would be the best way to go. Especially if Fallout is something we could go on.In Fallout 2 specifically, one of the great tactical CRPG classics, an atomic post-apocalyptic wasteland is a pretty fun place. You can pretty much do whatever you want.Fallout 2 takes place after the events of Fallout 1, with your character from the first game starting their own village outside the Vault to live out the rest of their days. Your new character is a descendant of them, and has grown up outside the Vault. Their village has had a horrible drought, and it's up to you as The Chosen One to set off and save the world.Fallout 2 is near identical to the first game in terms of gameplay, polished and upgraded to make it the definitive classic Fallout experience. If you're looking for the very best in terms of isometric, tactical CRPG action, Fallout 2 is probably your game.The time limit is gone. You're free to explore Fallout 2's vast, open world to your heart's content. There's all sorts of side-quests, missions, and just random nonsense to get yourself into. You can join the mafia, become a pornstar, or just slaughter every human being you see. It's all free game.To start, you just need to create your character. There is a selection of pre-made ones, but the real fun of the game is creating your own character to fully immerse yourself in the world of Fallout.From there, you just need to play through what could be called a crude tutorial dungeon. After that, the world opens up. Slowly at first, as your stats will not allow much exploration when the wasteland is crawling with giant scorpions and freaks. But with time, you'll be able to do as you please.Mechanically, it's better than the original Fallout. It plays better, it controls better, and it has more depth than the original in terms of what the world offers. The gameplay has been balanced to make all character skills viable, which was an issue with the first Fallout game. As a sequel, it definitely has at least improved upon the original.However, I personally still prefer the first one. Fallout 2, I felt took a lot of what made Fallout special out of the equation. The time limit, while brutal, was part of giving that sensation of hopelessness and urgency. And having your character born outside of a Vault, it took some of the impact away of having stepped out into the wasteland for the first time.The story was not as compelling, and it didn't really feel like Fallout at first to me. The early game is particularly slow, and it takes a while to really capture that Fallout vibe.As an older game, it is still a little bit dated. Especially in the graphics department. But still completely enjoyable as a game. I always did have a thing for older games. I like them a little mature, you know?Regardless, Fallout 2 is still a very special game. There aren't very many other games where you can blow up small children with powerful explosives, become a slaver, or have sex with a mutant. Fallout 2 really is something special, and it's an essential part of any PC game collection. The sheer depth of the game constantly gives off the feeling that there's still more to do and more to see.In the event of a real nuclear apocalypse, I call dibs on leader of the pornstar mafia. No, I already got dibs, it's official. Too bad. You can be something else.I called it, it's mine.

Long time fallout fan but never played 1&2. At first its very difficult. Combats in early levels are such hardcore RNG based. But after a while you realize you dont have to fight everything at all. This game doesnt force you to fight like 3 and 4 did.Anyway, if you get past the clunkiness and stuff you are in for a great and very atmospheric/immersive game. Loving it by far now!

												Now that Interplay has lost the rights to Bethesda, the new ownership has decided to patch the glitch that would cause your game to black out every few minutes and/or the random rainbowish colors that would be there in error due to the incompatibility problems caused by newer systems. This pretty much saves you a few minutes if you couldn't figure out the problem yourself online. Nonetheless, the game itself has an enriching storyline that even pleases graphics-spoiled gamers like me. I would really recommend this to anyone who has played any part of the newer fallout series such as Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas but wants to know the backstories to various references in the newer games, such as the origin of Marcus at Jacobstown in Fallout: New Vegas or Harold at the Oasis in Fallout 3. Overall I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for fun games in general.

content:

												Builds on everything I had problems with in the first game: The companions, and travel mainly. I only got one playthrough into this and it took 40 well-spent hours away from me, it felt like a small MMO or something with all the content and quests and cities to explore. What's more, it drastically builds upon the political ideas behind the game, as FO1 mainly had just the authoritarian left that was the Master, FO2 now has Vault City as a criticism of democracy, the NCR as a pushy police state/democracy and the Enclave who stood for forced eugenics, absolutely awesome stuff. Even though the pop-culture references and less serious atmosphere only slightly take away from the game, it's a very, very solid 10/10 from me. Would ride that Highwayman into the sunset any day of the week.

												Fallout 2 is a great game, and perhaps one of the best in the Fallout series. The setting, characters, and music are all wonderful. However, the combat is very dated and the game is infested with bugs. Certain quests and outcomes are simply unobtainable. In addition, I was annoyed that for a game that features many different solutions to complete a task, the game would often force you into doing things during crucial moments that if you had not previously focused upon, would be very difficult to do. Still, I can overlook this and say it is a game that any western rpg player should try out.

content:
er 25, 2016
												Simply the best game I've ever played. It's ancient by gaming standards (came out 1998), and I still keep coming back again and again, usually after playing another RPG and feeling it was, once again, missing something or doing something wrong (like not being Fallout 2).To me the biggest fault in Fallout 2 is that most people who have played it will never REALLY be satisfied with any other RPG. Ever. Yeah, in the new games the graphics might be better (by a lightyear) or the game mechanics might be insanely good and inventive, but when push comes to shove nothing really compares. The plot, the writing, the characters, the freedom, the harshness of the world, the humor AND the fact that your character build does actually REALLY affect your run - drop your INT low enough and almost all NPCs A) treat you like you were an idiot (which you, in fact, are) B) don't really feel inclined to trust you to take care of their problems (duh, you're an idiot). A really stupid character has his own way of getting things done (like accidentally selling himself as a slave), and the fact that the developers thought of all these things and incorporated them in to their game is - by the way - awesome. Simply awesome.

content:
er 24, 2016
												Fallout 4 is a great game, but it is not a great Fallout game.Fallout 2, this game right here, was the first truly post-apocalyptic RPG where every choice had consequences, your character stats mattered, and the replayability of another character was NOT just cookie-cutter. You could actually build a character too weak to survive the first zone, instead of just doing 10% more damage with weapom type x.You most certainly did not get laser weapons, power armor, and a minigun to kill a deathclaw from an elevated position in your first play session. Your choices did not all result in the same outcome, nobody held your hand through a tutorial (in fact, you probably died in the first 5 minutes), and you the player could not over-ride your character's abilities by aiming better or jumping on top of something or or or ...I only have 41.3 hrs on record with the Steam re-release. However, I have two worn-out CD-ROM discs, a playable third in a binder, a GoG version somewhere, and a very real understanding of video game addiction.

content:
er 23, 2016
Nostalgia GaloreWord cannot describe how much I love this game and I have lost count of how many times I have played it from beginning to end. Even though the game is ridiculously bugged and in many ways flawed (in its original form); the gritty grainy charm, the uncompromising dialogue and gory pixilated body explosions on a critical hit or by using a massive enough gun are just unparalleled, even when compared to the more modern instalments of the franchise. The retro pop-50s, hilariously grotesque depiction of a post-apocalyptic future is iconic and unmatched, it creates a post-eschatological environment that is equally gruesome as it is enjoyable. With that said, I love all of the other iterations of the game universe including those done by Bethesda, even Fallout 4, but none of them really compare to Fallout 2, only New Vegas comes close. I cherish my adventures with Sulik and his dialogue with his nose-bone, I laugh every time I buff John Cassidy in the heat of battle but forget his heart condition leading to his demise and of course the possibility of being reunited with Dogmeat from Fallout 1. I also love that you can make a character with such a low intelligence score that virtually all dialogue is impossible (as you are more or less unable to speak) and yet, you can complete the game in a meaningful way. I will be playing this game again and again, and force my children to do that same.And if they refuse, I will disown them. This game is indeed; a kiss to build a dream on..   ** This is a review of the original game, not Bethesda’s polished version.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2015
												Fallout 2, like it's predecessor and sequels, stands to date as one of the greatest roleplaying games ever devised. First introduced to the original game in the series as a youth, I quickly became addicted to both the setting and the story being told; I loved the choices you were asked to make, and the customisation options that were available to you; I adored the pre-war 50s feel that inhabited the wasteland, even as you carried plasma rifles and power armour into battle.In a word, Fallout 2, like the other games in the series, is sublime. As a fan of roleplaying games in general, I recognise that the post-apocalyptic genre is harder than others to make enticing - and yet Fallout somehow manages to nail it. Gore and mature themes meet head on with quirky humour, memorable locations and characters (Dogmeat and Harold the Ghoul being just two), and an expansive world to explore.Unlike the first game in the series, Fallout 2 has you taking on the role of a tribal youth who is sent out into the wasteland in order to secure a G.E.C.K. - a Garden of Eden Creation Kit - which will help your primitive people make the land furtile and liveable again. Who your character is - what gender, what they're good at, what their quirks are - is entirely up to you, as are the dialogue and moral decisions you make, and the route you take across the wasteland. With side quests all over the place, you can spend hours after hours trudging through the Fallout world, making your mark as either a sentinel of justice, or a madman with a shotgun. Good or evil, hero or villian - it's entirely up to you.The latter games might be controversial to a select few - after all, not everyone liked Bethesda's treatment of a classic game, and it's their perogative to think that way. However, it's almost unanimous fact that Fallout 2, like it's predecessor, stands as one of the greatest RPGs ever made.Buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2016
												Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a role-playing open world game featuring a considerably larger map/world and a far more extensive storyline, than those of Fallout 1. It is hands down one of the best games I've ever played (and that says a lot about it). The fact that the game was made in 1998 makes it even more impressive.Fallout 2 centres around the protagonist a.k.a. 'The Chosen One' and is entasked with the duty by the elder of his village to find and retrieve the Garden Eden Creation Kit (G.E.C.K.) which is a device that can create thriving communities out of the post-apocalyptic wasteland.The game comprises of exploring and travelling in the open world as well as speech and quests to various characters and NPC. In addition to the role playing elements, a unique turn-based shooter is used during combat. This incredible blend  makes the game so widely stimulating and intense. It is an experience unlike one other. Not to mention the storyline is as engaging as it is compelling.The player's actions throughout the game dictate what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. A player can choose to inhibit/aid certain NPCs and affects the entire gameplay. Aside from combat, speech also plays a huge role in the final outcome of the game. Before the game begins, the player is allowed to create his/her character with a variety of different skill, perk, trait and character point (S.P.E.C.I.A.L) builds. Because of the extensive outcome and scenarios, Fallout 2 is a game with incredibly high replay value.There is not much else to say, this game is IN-F***ING-CREDIBLE!GET IT (if you haven't already)6*/5 - 110% would recommend

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2013
												The good, the bad and the ugly for Fallout 2.Fallout is one of those game franchises that gives me he warm-tingly feeling just thinking about the games and while Bethesda has made some great sequels with Fallout 3 and New Vegas, by far one of my favorite games of all time has to be this instalment.Now, just to save time the review of this game could be applied to the original Fallout game with one major difference; there’s no annoying time limit. Now, sure the lack of that time limit may affect some’s perspective of realism but I think the freedom to explore and do side-quests makes the game more enjoyable but that’s just my opinion.The good:Grittiness of stories, environments, and characters has been something that’s been fairly popular in today’s gaming culture but nothing that’s come out recently could hold a candle to this game. Throughout the game you’re subjected to a very harsh environment where even the most civilized towns seems to have a dark streak that plays into the general feeling that the world is, in fact, completely screwed up and it’s up to you (ironically titled “the chosen one”) to save not only your village but the whole region from various forms of corruption and evil. Or you know… not… that’s what’s so great about this game! It gives you real choices on how you want to address problems you come across. Do you want to kill the slavers holding onto a mission critical NPC? Or do you want to trade in a companion and join them? Do you want to work towards putting a stop to the growing chem addicts in the region? Or ensure the chems keep flowing freely? Sorry, I kind of got off topic there. Bottom line, this game’s dark themes and choices give this game a level of depth that makes replays all the more enjoyable.The Bad:Some of the problems that gripped old PC games like this is they are often under-developed. It’s hard to tell if they just ran out of time on some things or in the case of things like the child-killer perk they were just WAY too controversial to be put in at release. Some of the things they took out though honestly would have made the game more enjoyable. If you have the time, do some research and take the time to get a good unofficial patch to restore some of these missing pieces.The ugly:The learning curve… Look, this game is not for the meek. You’re going to die and you’re going to die a lot. It falls under the category of old-school rpgs where even the easiest difficulties can be brutal for those who don’t know what to expect playing a game like this. In fact, if you don’t know what you’re getting into playing this game I’d warn you that you will probably restart a few times until you can get a character build that works for you (I recommend custom builds) and just like with all old games like these SAVE OFTEN.Story: 8/10Development: 2/10Nuka-nostalgia: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2016
												Simply the best game I've ever played. It's ancient by gaming standards (came out 1998), and I still keep coming back again and again, usually after playing another RPG and feeling it was, once again, missing something or doing something wrong (like not being Fallout 2).To me the biggest fault in Fallout 2 is that most people who have played it will never REALLY be satisfied with any other RPG. Ever. Yeah, in the new games the graphics might be better (by a lightyear) or the game mechanics might be insanely good and inventive, but when push comes to shove nothing really compares. The plot, the writing, the characters, the freedom, the harshness of the world, the humor AND the fact that your character build does actually REALLY affect your run - drop your INT low enough and almost all NPCs A) treat you like you were an idiot (which you, in fact, are) B) don't really feel inclined to trust you to take care of their problems (duh, you're an idiot). A really stupid character has his own way of getting things done (like accidentally selling himself as a slave), and the fact that the developers thought of all these things and incorporated them in to their game is - by the way - awesome. Simply awesome.

content:
22, 2016
												Best. Game. Ever.Nostalgia! The feelings! I have finished the game several times, finding something new each and every playthrough when I was a kid. The best part is that when the Internet came, I have googled for a playthhrough description and still found a couple of new unknown things to do in this game, that's how thought through it is, that is how much effort have been put in it. It's a masterpeace of gaming. It's a legend! It's Fallout!Even at the time it was released, the graphics were considered a downside of this game. Half-Life was released about that time with much better 3D graphics.The lack of graphics makes this game trick your brain into turning it's imagination center on or whatever it is called. It's like a book, makes you dream while you are awake, imagine how the caracters and places would look like in real life, placing you directly into the wasteland. That is why Fallout 3 and New Vegas will never be better than this to me, they look not as I have imagined it to be as a kid.The music is on point! The sounds, the instruments used add to the atmosphere of the place. The first second you are in New Reno you understand that mobsters and gangsters rule the place. Or Gecko? In Gecko you feel the place is dead even is ghouls are walking and talking and ready to beat your ♥♥♥ after they caught you stealing. Still, the music tells you life abandoned this place long ago. To this day I can tell by heart which melody plays in which place of the map.Dialogues... Just call Enclave from teminal in Gecko and you will understand that dialogues are the heart of this game. The can be very serious and almost existential, they can be simple and super fun. Basically, 50% of the time playing this game you are sitting and reading through millions of lines of dialogue. The other half you are looting, kicking ♥♥♥, levelling up your character, buying and selling stuff, picking locks. But the majority of time you are carefully reading not to miss a clue on a quest or simply cause it is interesting.Combination of this three things made a perfect game for me. As this review starts, this is the best game ever for me and I do not think this will ever change.Still playing this from time to time. Damn this game is good.On the downside - I feel really old. Ancient. I work with people who are younger than this game, that is how ancient I am.P.S. I know that nobody will read this review. I pay my respect to this game this way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 4, 2012
												The sequel to Fallout (reviewed here if you're curious), released a year afterwards in 1998. It's bigger and more ambitious than the first game, with more quests, more items and more locations. Even the tone of the game is lighter: more 'epic quest with comedic elements' than 'save your home from doom in the dystopian wasteland', although that element is certainly still there. The wasteland is even starting to rebuild in places - a theme that New Vegas would revisit.Of course, not every writer consistently strikes gold. Fallout 2's writing contains more scattershot comedy, with less of an emphasis on your quest to save your village from starvation. Which might not hit the mark with everyone, this being a relatively hardcore niche title released in 1998 and developed by a team that was almost entirely if not 100% male. But don't despair: there's a solid game here for RPG fans nevertheless.Base gameplay is much the same as in Fallout: gaining XP to level up and allocating skill points/choosing perks, turn-based combat that uses Action Points, hex-based movement in locations, and wasteland travel between settlements - this time with an optional car!The interface and companion management is definitely improved from Fallout's. Among other things, the inventory menu isn't tedious to use, you can now trade money in sums containing five figures, and you have much greater control over your companions' battle tactics/equipment. Your companions also level up with you.Graphics are obviously the same style as Fallout, and FO2 even uses some of the first game's music. Good thing the new tracks are also excellent and evocative. You can download all of the remastered classic Fallout music here[auralnetwork.com].Much like Fallout, the patched Steam release is pretty buggy, up to and including serious bugs in main quests that can pretty much prevent you from finishing the game. I would suggest downloading killap's Unofficial Patch from his website[www.killap.net]. For those of you interested, he also made the Restoration Project mod, which adds a bunch of cut content.Fallout 2's early game is more difficult than Fallout's. The first game gave you a gun right from the beginning, and pointed you in a relatively easy direction. Fallout 2 starts with the Temple of Trials, which is an overly lengthy, somewhat implausible and definitely annoying tutorial-by-fire that is ten times more frustrating if your character isn't skilled at Melee Weapons or any of the other tested skills. If you picked any of the less-than-optimal skills, the whole game gets that much harder. Its only saving grace is that it lets you level up a few times. Most of the rest of the game afterwards is much better.After that ordeal, there are a few quests you can do in your home village before you set out, which are usually a good idea. It'll be several more XP levels and a couple of towns before you find a firearm worth anything. Your options will expand from there, although you're still kind of vulnerable until you find good armor and good weapons you're skilled with. It'll be another while yet before you can clear rooms by yourself, and even in the late game that's not always possible unless you explicitly made a character to do so.It's worth noting that there are many more high-tier weapons in each class to choose from, as opposed to Fallout where the turbo plasma rifle and gatling laser reigned supreme. True, the pulse rifle does the most damage, but now you have more options across multiple weapon skills and styles for when focusing on DPS doesn't quite cut it.Overall, it's a good game and a worthy sequel, but watch out for Lynnette.She doesn't like you.

content:
22, 2016
												Best. Game. Ever.Nostalgia! The feelings! I have finished the game several times, finding something new each and every playthrough when I was a kid. The best part is that when the Internet came, I have googled for a playthhrough description and still found a couple of new unknown things to do in this game, that's how thought through it is, that is how much effort have been put in it. It's a masterpeace of gaming. It's a legend! It's Fallout!Even at the time it was released, the graphics were considered a downside of this game. Half-Life was released about that time with much better 3D graphics.The lack of graphics makes this game trick your brain into turning it's imagination center on or whatever it is called. It's like a book, makes you dream while you are awake, imagine how the caracters and places would look like in real life, placing you directly into the wasteland. That is why Fallout 3 and New Vegas will never be better than this to me, they look not as I have imagined it to be as a kid.The music is on point! The sounds, the instruments used add to the atmosphere of the place. The first second you are in New Reno you understand that mobsters and gangsters rule the place. Or Gecko? In Gecko you feel the place is dead even is ghouls are walking and talking and ready to beat your ♥♥♥ after they caught you stealing. Still, the music tells you life abandoned this place long ago. To this day I can tell by heart which melody plays in which place of the map.Dialogues... Just call Enclave from teminal in Gecko and you will understand that dialogues are the heart of this game. The can be very serious and almost existential, they can be simple and super fun. Basically, 50% of the time playing this game you are sitting and reading through millions of lines of dialogue. The other half you are looting, kicking ♥♥♥, levelling up your character, buying and selling stuff, picking locks. But the majority of time you are carefully reading not to miss a clue on a quest or simply cause it is interesting.Combination of this three things made a perfect game for me. As this review starts, this is the best game ever for me and I do not think this will ever change.Still playing this from time to time. Damn this game is good.On the downside - I feel really old. Ancient. I work with people who are younger than this game, that is how ancient I am.P.S. I know that nobody will read this review. I pay my respect to this game this way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												One of my favorite RPGs and games in general. Sequel to the first post-nuclear simulator, Fallout 2 retained the same good qualities of the first Fallout with an experience just as good. Fallout 2 doesn't change too much in comparison to its predecessor in terms of the actual gameplay mechanics, but the the improvements and more content, like improved companions and a larger game world, are a welcome that offers plenty of replay value. The charm of Fallout 2 is the change in the nature from the first. The wasteland has progressed greatly in the last 80 years since the events of Fallout, and it offers a much different atmosphere. Trees are starting to grow back again, settlements as large as cities rebuild, governments forming, civilization is getting back on its feet. And with that comes a constant struggle for power across the waste among these different factions. And throughout the game the fate of these factions depend on your actions. The world feels more alive and its a welcome change to see how the universe has progressed since the Vault Dweller walked the wasteland.Along side these changes to the atmosphere comes a much different approach to the game. It's seemingly more satirical with many pop culture references and breaking of the fourth wall. It's different from what you'd expect from Fallout but its can be humorous enough to get a chuckle out of it when you get the references.However, there is one major flaw with this game and it's the bugs; and there are a lot. What I would say is the biggest issue with the bugs are with the quest. Many of the quest in the game are heavily bugged, even to the point that it can completely block off an entirely different path to completing a quest which is rather disappointing because you'll have to settle for a lesser outcome rather than the one you desired. It's a real shame too because Black Isle Studios did some outstanding work with quest design, but the experience is held back by the nasty bugs. Despite these issues, I am still able to forgive the game for the rest of the great work put into it.In the end, it's the Fallout you've always loved but with the added joy of getting addicted to Jet, becoming a pornstar, or punching children with a mega powerfist because they thought it was a good idea to steal from the Chosen One. And then later you'll be labeled as 'Child Killer'.

												The sequel to the classic Fallout, not only does this contain many improvements over the original, but it also contains great gameplay and writing that is just no doubt better than most AAA RPGs of today. This game is the sole reason so many Fallout fans hate Bethesda. They ruined the franchise with the removal of a lot of great, classic RPG elements, a complete overhaul (for the worse) of the game's style and hiring the most boring people you could ever know as writers. This is a very old-school game and it screams nostalgia. A real blast to the past. This was also the big breakthrough for LGBT equality in video games. You can be gay in this game. Also, it was the first game to feature gay marriage, which was illegal in US back in 1998. This whole package, as well as Planescape: Torment and Icewind Dale, all of it just makes me miss Black Isle. 9/10.

												This is one of my favorite games of all time. It is very old but that does not take away anything from it. The begining of the game is extreamly bad. Another is where you go to a bar on one side of town where drinks are twice as much as a bar on the other side of town and you can do a quest where you go snooping around looking for the reason those drinks are so low. In the begining of the game you won't have much and combat can be a little difficult since in fast travel it brings you to a map where you click around in the direction the NPC's told you the next city is which is very unique and interesting. Although sometimes you will run into a group of bandits ir wild animals trying to kill you and since there are edges of the land that you are on you can just run away very easily. Over all this is a great game.

content:
y 5, 2016
												Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a role-playing open world game featuring a considerably larger map/world and a far more extensive storyline, than those of Fallout 1. It is hands down one of the best games I've ever played (and that says a lot about it). The fact that the game was made in 1998 makes it even more impressive.Fallout 2 centres around the protagonist a.k.a. 'The Chosen One' and is entasked with the duty by the elder of his village to find and retrieve the Garden Eden Creation Kit (G.E.C.K.) which is a device that can create thriving communities out of the post-apocalyptic wasteland.The game comprises of exploring and travelling in the open world as well as speech and quests to various characters and NPC. In addition to the role playing elements, a unique turn-based shooter is used during combat. This incredible blend  makes the game so widely stimulating and intense. It is an experience unlike one other. Not to mention the storyline is as engaging as it is compelling.The player's actions throughout the game dictate what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. A player can choose to inhibit/aid certain NPCs and affects the entire gameplay. Aside from combat, speech also plays a huge role in the final outcome of the game. Before the game begins, the player is allowed to create his/her character with a variety of different skill, perk, trait and character point (S.P.E.C.I.A.L) builds. Because of the extensive outcome and scenarios, Fallout 2 is a game with incredibly high replay value.There is not much else to say, this game is IN-F***ING-CREDIBLE!GET IT (if you haven't already)6*/5 - 110% would recommend

content:
er 25, 2016
												A true gem of rpg genre. Timeless classic which never becomes boring and, surprisingly enough, outdated.When I bought my first pc long time ago F2 was one the first games I installed and since that time it's still one of my favorite. And I'm still have that old cd full of old scratches.Rich world with charismatic characters, wide variety of story-impacting decisions, post-nuclear atmosphere, turn-based combat and just fun. Where else can your character become a pornstar (no videos sadly, just your own imagination), find a Holy Hand Grenade, been referred as a "walking refrigerator" and feel yourself as a skilfull diplomat even your character was under performance-enhancing drugs and had a huge heavily-armed supermutant at the back looking curiously at slightly shy local inhabitants? And you can't put a price tag on that unforgettable feeling when your Chosen One receives Expert Excrement Expeditor perk.And there was real supermutants before Bethesda made a typical orcs out of them.If you've ever been curious about the games which made significant contribution to the evolution of rpg genre you just must to try this masterpiece.PS. And don't forget to download high resolution patch.

content:
ry 27, 2014
												A post-apocalyptic turn-based RPG like no other.This game is a classic. I've put in hundreds of hours in it playing different ways with different characters before I added it to my steam library (I own the discs for 1 and 2). The game has a good mix of stat/skill building and loot collection. For its time, the cutscenes are pretty good. There's little to be desired in such a classic game.The ability to choose your path in this game is beyond astounding for such an old game. If you remember when Fable came out, people freaked out because you could choose your own path. Fallout has done that stuff way before such games. If you like to be a jerk or a good guy, you can do either to your hearts content.Fallout has some of the most memorable designs and lore of any post-apocalyptic setting I've seen, and I would definitely recommend it for anyone who enjoys a good turn-based, isometric RPG romp.Easily a 10/10 game. As good in my childhood as it is in my adulthood, a timeless classic.

content:
11, 2014
												<3 <3 <3This is my all-time favorite game. Why? ...That's hard to pinpoint. The open world? Only the vaugest hint of linearity? The shenanigans? The trouble-making? The snark. The sardonic, grim humor of a post-apocolyptic world inhabited by humans (tribal and "civilized"), ghouls, mutants, and more.If you wondered about ~any~ of the backstory in F:NV, Fallout 1 and 2 will fill in the gaps. Fallout: New Vegas is the direct sequel to Fallout 2; Fallout 3 is what happens when a company aquires an IP with a rich internal history and says, Eh, let's move everything across the country because who wants to play in -that- world anymore? Me, that's who. This is the 3rd copy I've owned (because I'm terrible at keeping track of install CDs), and now I have it forever (or, at least as long as Steam servers are up).Whole-hearted recommendation to any RPG fan, any turn-based combat fan, or ~anyone~ with a dark sense of humor.

												One of the few games I recommend without hesitation.  Fallout 3 (a.k.a.: Oblivion 2) is total garbage, which completely lacks the mechanical equality, spirit, aesthetics and depth of its predecessors.  Fallout 3 is an open-world FPS that lacks the integral granularity to exist a an RPG, yet passes itself off as one as effectively as Steve Buscemi in drag.The REAL Fallout series represents an almost unparallelled RPG system in its complexity, balance and replayability.  Fallout is, without hyperbole, also one of the most influential games in history; it literally is the foundation for much of the modern PC (and PnP) RPG paradigm.Out of all the hundreds of RPGs I've played, Fallout 1&2 are still unquestionably in my top 5.
