content:
5
												Fallout 2 is a classic, a legend that stands amongst legends. The equal of every great CPRG that came before it, and superior to most that came after it, this game has aged gracefully and still holds the charm it did when I first booted it up nearly 2 decades ago as a younger lad.You play as the Chosen One, a villager from a dying tribe who is sent on a hail Mary quest to recover an ancient device rumored to return dead wasteland to verdant fields: the Garden of Eden Creation Kit, or G.E.C.K. for short. This is not a new plot device, it is not terribly original to be the only man or woman in the world capable of saving your people. However, the execution of this quest is what sets Fallout 2 apart from even it's own successors. You are given almost complete freedom to be anyone you want in this world. You can be a sociopathic killer, an opportunistic slaver, a drug-addled genius, or a savior to the common man and the tread upon. Your character, and how you are reacted to and perceived is entirely based on your choices. An interaction I recall from my very first playthrough many years ago had someone asking my sarcastic little thief of a character what being a tribesman was all about, and did we eat our dead like he'd heard? My answer was thus: "Of course, how else would I grok their essence? Just sauté what you want to eat in a light garlic sauce. Delicious."As a top-down, or isometric, turn-based game, this is slower than most modern games. There's next to no handholding, as the game will frequently murder you for taking on fights you couldn't handle, or frankly just for fun. RNG is a large factor here. However, the gameplay holds as true now as it did then. Plot your moves, mind your enemies, and bask in the glory of every hard-won battle. Of course, for every victory there can be defeat, and you should be prepared for it if you've not played a game of this type before.While dated by anyone's standards, the graphics serve their purpose with charm and readability; and more importantly it supports modern monitors, no patching required. There is a fan-made patch you can use that many will recommend, but I haven't tried it. Haven't felt I needed it.This game is my go-to. I've owned probably 5 or 6 copies of it over the years, and whenever I find myself somewhere where Internet is scarce and my battery is a consideration, it never fails me. If you are in the mood for old-school role-playing magic, you've found it.

content:
r 3, 2016
												Tags : Isometric RPG - Post Apocalyptic*HALL OF FAME* *ALL TIME FAVORITES*On July 15, 2016 a Bethesda backed translation of a Czech mod for Fallout 2 called Fallout 1.5 has surfaced on the internet. I hear from articles in the news that it is the same size as fallout 1, feature the grittier tone of fallout 1, but has a ton of quests in it. We need to somehow petition steam to put this on the store as a steam mod for Fallout 2!!!No mutants allowed has a fair amount of downloadable locations for fallout 2 - and some mods aggregate a ton of other mods and some bugfixes into them. I am not sure how much of this has been made redundant with the remastered editions of the fallout trilogy to work on older systems but it is definitely worth checking out before you start a playthrough. You can get more locations, more quests, and some new items. Otherwise this is the same awesome kind of content as fallout 1, the main difference being that you can no longer fail the main arc by making the wrong choice or dicking around too long anymore. A feature that used to be present if heavily relaxed in v1.0 but that was just taken out altogether through patching. There are a ton more pop culture references and jokes here and some people might miss the grittier fallout 1 style of handling things. The brand new campaign is longer, NPC control has been improved, skills have been slightly reworked, and the level cap pushed all the way to 99. Individually those differences dont seem like much but they add a lot of longevity to the title, and I end up spending a lot more times in fallout 2 just cruising around the wasteland fighting ennemies. If you intend to take this game very slow and max out your characters and have a semi-permanent game going then I suggest you download a mod that allows you to change the game over message timer. Indeed, because of a coding limitation back when the game was made, there is a definite amount of time you can spend in game before it abruptly ends on you and tells you the game is over, you will in essence, have reached the very last calendar day allowed by coding, which in game time is 13 years. Modders have found a way around this however and you can make this message appear straight as you leave arroyo or 50 years later in game time, meaning you could in theory roleplay the entire life of a character from age 19 to 60. Which is kind of awesome. At some point all you will have left to do is grind the wasteland so I suggest if you go for that route that you leave yourself some main quests going, no mutant allowed total mods can really help here by adding quests.Anyways enough ramblingMasterpiece

content:
13
												I'm going to be honest, I despised this game when I first played it. My attacks weren't doing ♥♥♥♥, I was extremely confused on what to do, and hated how it felt. That was months ago, until recently. I sat down, read some tips and tricks and gave this game a shot. Now I've 70 hours in this game. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ blast.Pros:-Interesting and well-developed plot: The more I got in, the more I wanted to see what was going on. The stroy hooked really hooked me in.-Interesting locations: Many locations you visit always have some backstory around them and I gotta say, almost all of them are interesting and awesome to visit like the casino of New Reno with mobsters hanging around running the place or even  Navarro which let's you infiltrate the enclave base as a recruit. -Choices Galore: There are many choices to make in californian wasteland and many I never even knew about until my second playthrough. There's so much you could miss on one playthrough that it makes me want to do another just to see what the other way could have been.-Dialogue and Writing: This game has the best writing in any fallout game hands down. There are many humerous moments that we come to love in fallout, but it knows when to be dark and disturbing. You'll want to talk to everyone just to see what they're gonna say. (Low intelligence runs are the funniest ♥♥♥♥ ever)-Combat: This is a hit and miss for some. For me, it's a hit. When you sit down and understand what to do, the combat goes from something you may despise to something you won't mind at all.Cons:-Confusion: This game can be pretty confusing at times. Don't be afraid to pull up a walkthrough to help you out because while some quests are easy to do especially if you actually read what they want you to do, there are other quests where I just questioned Wtf am I supposed to do. Then when I do figure it out, I just think how tf was I supposed to know that. -Useless perks: There are some perks in this game that I took on my first playthrough that I thought would be good, only later to find out how useless they are and pretty much ruin my run. Traps and Gambling are prime examples of perks that you're rarely ever use most of the time. Watch out what you pick. You could really bone your run if you choose booty perks.Conclusion: This game may not be for everyone, but I urge you, stick with it. This is a kind of game I don't think we'll ever see today again. It's got laughs, it's got amazing writing, decent combat, some actual balls compared to newer fallouts (like being able to kill children and some of the subject matter) and it's just so damn interesting. Consider me a fallout 2 fan. This game rises as the best fallout game IMO.PS: Get the restoration project mod too! It adds cut content back into the game that makes the journey even cooler. (Just be sure to follow a guide for that too if you get stuck) :)

												Fun and rewarding game but with a few problems.*It's really easy to gimp your character from the start because so many traits and perks are just useless.*You will be spending your first 5-6 hours killing rats because there are to few early-game quests to get you started. The game does get a whole lot easier once you get a mid-game weapon though.*The game has some glitches and slowdowns that can ♥♥♥♥ you over if you don't have backup saves. (There are fan patches that fix these though)*Energy weapons, First aid, Doctor Melee weapons and Traps are Throwaway skills in my opinion. Not worth leveling.*♥♥♥♥ you Lynette nobody likes you!With that said, the rest of the game is prima salami, go buy it.

content:
er 26, 2014
												Well this game is great.  I played this for much longer than Fallout 1 and there is reason for that.  This game has so much more content than the first.  There are many more quests and many more places to explore and visit.  This game is turning into one of my favorites because of everything the game is.  The guns are amazing to and all different.  What took the cake for this game was the dialouge and story.  The story far exeeds the first in depth and feel.  You feel like such a badass after the ending and feel satisfied.  The game is a memorable one for good reason.  What I didn't like about the game is that I wished that the Enclave were a better enemy faction.  I wish there were more to them so I can hate them more.  They did do things that were terrible to me but I didn't feel like they did much.  I guess that is the downside to isometric story driven games.  It is a great game and worth a buy.

content:
ry 2
The sequel to Fallout (1997); this game takes place 8 years after the first game following the same protagonist.

The game mechanics are the same like the first game, but with NPC improvements.
This storyline is set for you to save a village and explore new areas.

If you liked the original Fallout game you'll still enjoy this one.

7/10

content:
er 8, 2013
												Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game. I have many fond memories of this game, it is one of my all time favorites and even after all these years, after all the hours and hours and hours I have put into the game across several different computers; I can still play it shamelessly for hours and never get bored. Its like a great film that you never tire of. I bought Fallout 2 back in '99, as a teen and could not stop playing it. I ended up becoming so engrossed in the game, that I took to the internet and found myself at the No Mutants Allowed forums where I started a long running RP called Fallout: Systematic Annihilation (My name was TRAG on those boards.) The RP was a little hit on the website, and we had quite a few fans that read it regularly and even joined in the fun. But, I didn't stop there- Chris Avellone started releasing a little document called- The Fallout Bible. I was pulled in yet again. I have read that Bible more than once- I even have a digital copy on my cell phone for my reading pleasure. Yeah, this game started an obsession. Thankfully, it never got bad enough to where restraining orders were necessary (This is a joke of course, but there are those out there that have gone that far). So, you have read how this game has touched my life, and inspired my imagination. Now, you are probably wondering- where is the review!?! Fallout 2 is an isometric post apocalyptic role playing game with turn-based combat. That being said, this is not just any isometric RPG, this is one of the most well written, deep, open world rpgs ever crafted. Your choices here carry real weight within the world- Want to be a Slaver? A rough, hard living slave catcher/seller. All you have to do is get a tattoo on your forehead that the world can see and you can be one. The only problem is that people really do see it and their reactions to you will reflect that. Needless to say, Slavers aren't exactly welcome in many places in the wasteland. You may wish to rethink that life choice. But, this game is not just about career choice, this is a game with a deep strategic combat system that will challenge even the most hardened RPG gamer. The game does not hold your hand and more than likely you will die a lot. Saving often is the best tool in your arsenal, and you will be relieved when you can reload your game only a few moments before you told that Super Mutant and his pals to shove it up his you know what, and instead he shoved it up yours...Lets move on.This is a CRPG in every sense of the word, so if you get the feel that there is a feeling that you could be playing this on a table with some friends and a cashe of multicolored dice, you probably could. In fact- There is a Pen and Paper version of the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system (the rules system the game is powered by.) on the internet and you can find it at No Mutants Allowed (the most well known Fallout fan site, find them here http://www.nma-fallout.com/ .) There is so much that I can say about this game, but I won't, because I believe that you owe it to yourself to see it with your own eyes.Fallout 2 is considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time for a reason: It lives up to the previous statement. It really is one of the greatest RPGs of all time. The writing is top notch, the sheer amount of choice and freedom. The methodical and satisfying development of your main character from an upstart, inexperienced tribal into a wasteland killing machine who is feared throughout the region, or a hero reveared by the struggling wasteland people. The choice is yours and your actions and decisions will determine the man/woman you become in this harsh and unforgiving post apocalyptic wasteland. You will need all the help you can get, and companions are there to meet and join your quest to restore your village and save its inhabitants from starvation, disease, and destruction.This game is so detailed for its time, that even today I am finding things I have never seen in the game before; and I have been playing it since 1999, a year after it was released! If that doesn't give you an idea of the replayability factor I don't know what will. If you purchase this game, you will come back to it year after year. And if you are a fan of pen and paper RPGS, CRPGS, or old school RPGs, then Fallout 2 is a godsend. Bigger and crazier than its predecessor Fallout (Which itself is an AMAZING game.) Fallout 2 takes you to the future that everyone hopes will never happen and lets you either wallow in it, or conquor it. I HIGHLY recommend this game for any RPG fan. It will ensnare you, it will inspire you!!

content:
r 16, 2014
												I can't believe I haven't got round to writing a review for this game already!Fallout is a role playing game with an excellent story run throughout the series. This game is one of the best games I have ever played and it is a game that you can simply play through time and time again not only due to a wide range of choices but a story that you will want to hear again and again, admittedly the controls up until fallout 3 have been a bit primative and lack luster but they work if you're willing to give them a prod and experiment. Fallout 2 is an excellent addition to this series but the game either is for you or is not and with the excessive amount of bugs, primative style of controls and lacking graphics compared to todays top RPG's such as The elder scrolls I would only really reccomend this game is you really enjoyed fallout 3 and New vegas and would like to explore the story of fallout further; if you are one of those people who can't get enough of the fallout series this game is 100% for you, you will not be disappointed because the original games are just as good if not better than the recent ones except more primative.

content:
, 2016
												Fallout 2 is one of the best games ever created.It's a trun-based post apocalyptic rpg with an isometric view. You can create your own character by allowing stats (strengh increases melee damage aswell as carrying capacity, intellect determines how much skill points you get to spend when levelling up, etc ... ) You start as a native of a tribe from the north-west of the former USA now called the Wasteland and you're send out to find the fabled G.E.C.K. (Garden of Eden Creation Kit) to save your village.Great story, Great game. Hands down the best fallout game with fallout: new vegasThere is an unofficial patch that solves tons of bug and restores some of the cut content on the webThere is also a High Rez patch that enables you to play the game at today's screen resolutions on the web

												TL;DR: This game is FANTASTIC! But DON'T buy it from Steam. Get it from gog or somewhere else where you can find a older version.Longer version:If you were thinking about buying this game DON'T. This game was great before the update but they ♥♥♥♥ed it up and made the game worse.How?Before, I had about 30 saves of different characters. Now? Gone. No warning, nothing. All that progress is ♥♥♥♥ed. You can now only have ONE ♥♥♥♥ING TAB to save in which is about 10 slots. They also made the travelling system be slower so you're more likely to run into more deathclaws and die in one hit. Also, of course this breaks any type of mod (the fallout 2 restoration pack which was almost mandatory to play the game properly has now been broken by this update including all of my saves are broken/corrupt). I have no idea what the person who patched this game recently was thinking.  They've effectively just destroyed older players who got it before the update and made it tougher for newer players who don't know what they're doing.

content:
27
												Bizarre is a word that comes to mind when playing Fallout 2. Its a world both serious and very silly at the same time. The main quest is serious but the whole game is full of pop culture references and silly scenes, sex and drugs run rampant and it feel like almost everyone is a sneeze away from wanting to kill you.  I know this game is treated like a religion so people are going to hate me but I'm being honest despite the fact how someone can downvote this game while ignoring all peer pressure and being honest lol. I Installed a restoration patch which added many things although I was there mainly for bug fixes. My strange story included giving children an orphanage to get them off the streets, sleeping with a mob leaders wife while dealing with mobster wars in an even more lawless city, getting someones spleen back which he lost in a bet, moving a plant to another garden so he could teach me how to beat a Radscorpion at chess and many many more but mostly just shooting annoying obnoxious people in the face. The combat is pretty much the same as Fallout 1 and for me that is no bad thing with a few new weapons added andthe gory deaths are still here. I encountered many things in the world map such as knights looking for a holy hand grenade then right after meeting them again getting killed by a small rat despite their power armor, Darth Vadar and friends standing around chatting while Han Solo told me something there no match for a good blaster so gave me a blaster, a crashed ship with dead red shirts, a dead whale in the middle of the desert and a man guarding a bridge asking familiar questions, the Cafe of Broken Dreams and many more which you will probably recognise. Amongst the things I didn't like is Fallout 2 has many quests but alot of them are not obvious and this game needs a guide/walkthough more than most as many are at least semi hidden and even when you get them there is no reminder in your log where you had to go/do what. Such things will effect new players more and it can be and get very confusing especially amongst its bloated game world. The same with items, there is no description how things work and what they do such as drugs and medical items and which items are just vendor trash. Once again this effects new players more because once you know you remember but there is no harm with an ingame description but I do understand games were different when this was made. With NPC's too Its so easy to say '' the wrong thing '' which more so than Fallout 1 can suddenly turn even whole towns hostile and likely result in a last save game reload. Skill checks are still here but like Fallout 1 they are '' invisible '' so you may not know when you are using them. This game is also difficult , more so than Fallout 1 and companions are almost as annoying. Comparing to the later fallout games is hard because like the Fallout 1 they are so different especially the obvious Isometric vs First Person game worlds. Having said that Fallout 2 does feel very different to Fallout 1 in many ways too. I noticed when watching Bethesda's '' making of Fallout 3 video '' they would reference Fallout 1 but not Fallout 2 so I guess they had that more in mind. Overall I can see why people like this game and while I like easter eggs and the occasional joke this game takes things beyond silly so much which felt too distracting. Also I cannot be like one of those people who are like '' wow you can bea porn star 10/10 game'' . I spent along time experiencing what this game offers which I don't regret but honestly I prefer Fallout 1 as The story , atmosphere and locations feel more consistent and the lol sillyness is not everywhere you go. I did prefer certain things in Fallout 2 such as better inventory management, the car for faster transport (which is needed in this bigger map) and you can store items in and unlike Fallout 4 the characters are not making excuses to explain indepth or technical things for you. Not a terrible game if you can get over the archaic game design. Still try it for yourself you may like it like many others seem to and you can get it quite cheap these days in sales.

7, 2015
												It was going well with this game at first. It's the typical story, you know? Girl meets game, game and girl fall in love, girl meets another game, game gets jealous...It was like, there was nothing to be jealous of, you know? I liked both games just the same, for different reasons, and I wasn't gonna forget about this game! But this game just didn't understand.We fought, we argued, and neither of us could remember what it was like to be in love with each other any more.And that's such a sad feeling- it's bad enough to fall out of love, but I'd say it's even worse to forget what love felt like in the first place. We said we'd still speak after the break up, but we lost contact.I guess I'd still recommend the game, but I have to warn you, if your relationship with the game hits a roadblock...You might fall out.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												Black Isle at their finest.  Game is older than many gamers.  Reviewed ad nauseum, I will take this opportunity to impart an anecdote.I am currently playing thru this game.  I was getting annoyed at the engine.  Even 17 years ago, the hidden behind walls thing was mad annoying.  I have 1 full playthru, and many partials over that time, the last substantial one I stopped at New Reno.  That was 10 years ago.  I was in a town where there is an important NPC (skeeter) in a building that you can't see inside unless you run behind it.  The doors are on the hidden backside.  I knew as I played before, but was a little frustrated.  I was muttering about how Pillars better have screen rotation.  Then I randomly talked to an npc behind this building a bit.  This one was in view.  I asked about the other guy who is hidden a few steps away, and the NPC says "he's standing right there.  Use your eyes."  Those guys at Black Isle knew full well how frustrating not being able to see an npc standing 10 feet away right in front of you due to an immobile painted background, and put those lines in there.  I bet whoever wrote that bit snickered like I did.  I never read those lines before, in probably 100 hours of varied gameplay.  The nuance and subtlety is what is so great about this game.  The way characters are written, the storylines, and unsanitary reality of what harsh life does to mankind.  The good do indeed die young as even the good ones have some bad in this world.

1, 2015
												At this time writing this review I have only played about 85 minutes of the game but it took just that short of time to see how good of a game it is. At first I was skeptical because of the age of the game, but honestly that shouldn't be the deterance for this game. It's your top down, somewhat turned based, game but it's more than that. The game unlocks so much creativity to solving things outside of combat! Using your brain has never been more fun! Literally...Play this if:1. You are a big Fallout fan2. Enjoy "puzzles" (couldn't think of another word)3. Don't mind turned based combat (real time movement isn't turned based, only when initiating combat)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2016
												This is the Fallout franchise at its peak.  Taking the open world of a post-apocalyptic wasteland of the original and making it 10+ times bigger but keeping the charm of almost every location that you visit.  Every location is detailed and contains a bevy of unique and interesting characters.  This was in the era of audio dialogue and coupled with the computer generated faces of a range of notable characters from the story made this game very engulfing (except Myron, ♥♥♥♥ THAT GUY).  Add to that a list of amazing voice actors that fit their roles like a glove.  Before we got the idiotic Karma system of Fallout 3 (who is thinking of 'karma' in a dog-eat-dog wasteland?), we had the awesome system of reputation for each location (this was the influence for the faction rep in New Vegas) and it worked wonderfully.  I only wish that we could have experienced the original vision of Fallout 3 (Van Buren) instead of the Bethesda, barely-working abortion of Fallout 3.

content:
er 2, 2016
												Simply put Fallout 2 is a masterpiece. It improves upon Fallout 1 in virtually every way and it allows for such creative roleplaying and variety that I am still impressed that few games have surpassed this. You might want to be a slaver one playthrough and a pornstar the next who is also a champion boxer. What more do you want? Well if you want good companions you're in luck because Fallout 2 has the best companions in the whole series and they're not even comparable to the cardboard cutouts in Fallout 1.Superficially this looks just like Fallout 1 but more (the same opinion people had for New Vegas compared to 3) but the more you play it the more you realise it stands out as a wonderful game in its own right, not just as a sequel to another amazing CRPG.I'll admit that out of the 3 amazing Fallouts (1, 2 and New Vegas) this has my least favourite main quest and the final showdown is only a fraction as good as the confrontation with the Master. But despite all that Fallout 2 is an amazing game with few faults.

content:
29, 2015
												To be frank, I really enjoyed the game. I started playing it way after it was released, so this isn't a nostalgia trip for me or anything, this was from pure interest in the genre and what I've heard about it. I was not disappointed.This game is packed with content. There's lots of quests, characters, weapons, locations, and items. There's almost always 2 or 3 ways to resolve a conflict and the straightest path isn't always the best one. Most of your choices do have some sort of consequence. The combat can be pretty challenging, but can also be like super easy if you have the right build, it's not particularly well balanced. The visuals, well, they kind of hit the spot for what the game is portraying. Dark, dull, forboding, if not boring landscapes. I mean, you're in the middle of the desert, it's not that interesting. The humor is pretty cool, and I must have laughed a few times at either something happening or when a character said something funny. The story is pretty interesting overall, having you start as one of the previous PC's (from Fallout) decendants in a tribal community to helping out (or hurting) towns or refugees to disabling (or enabling) nukes.I think that anyone who can deal with turn-based rpgs should play this. It's pretty awesome. Even if you haven't played turn-based rpgs or maybe have had bad experiences with them, you should like this. But stay away if you can only handle fps style gameplay, this isn't for you.The steam version does work with all of the mods out there btw, I've not run into any issues regarding that stuff.10/10Would die in the first battle again.

content:
9, 2016
												QUICK STORY BEFORE I SHOW MY ACTUAL REVIEW:>me>knows little to nothing about fo2>has been playing off and on for past month or so>uses a build from the fo2 wiki called "gifted gunfighter">became a slaver at the beginning of the game, not knowing the consequences>made a bit of extra coin but got bored of capturing slaves>tries to leave but realizes i'm a permanent slaver b/c my slaver tattoo>has 0 access to the best companions for my build (Surik = previous slave, Cassidy = hates slavers, Vic died early b/c i'm dumb)>is companionless until i do the thing when you go to san fran first and then navarro for quick power armor>gets k9>k9 can't carry anything>sad>wanders around avoiding simple side quests, even the ones in Arroyo>luckily survives every encounter due to op power armor >gets this special encounter where i get dogmeat>dogmeat, also dog, cannot carry my things>starts focusing on getting new companions, most blocked off for me>figures out you can get a husband or wife>goes to that town so i can get free packrat companion>has sex with this one chick, accidentally (yes really)>father bursts in>ohno.png>asks what i'm doing>"full-body medical examination sir">"i don't believe you">etc etc>gets forced into a shotgun wedding>realizes this is the companion i'd get>"maybe she is good with melee">nope.avi>she can't level up, can't carry more than 100lb, has 33 hp, is best unarmed>sigh, it'll do>does sidequest where i get yet another pointless dog who cannot carry anything>full party with a dumb wife who won't leave my side, 2 dogs that can't carry anything, and a robodog who, you guessed it, can't carry anything either>goes to tanker in san fran to get it over with>goes down a floor to fight the weirdo alien wana-whatchamacallets>k9 kicks alien ♥♥♥♥>dogmeat doesn't get much dmg off but takes a lot of it surprisingly>lassie, the other dog, dies almost instantaneously>wife lingers around by my side saying everything is dark>whyme.png>figures it is useless, loads back to before going down a floor>pulls shotty out that i stole from gun store owner>shoots wife, body falls to floor and all that>no one cares>"i got a wife because of a shotgun wedding, now i lost a wife because of a shotgun">later gets intelligent-hooded-deathclaw companion that carrys 250lb, takes dmg, and deals dmg>beats game in less than an hour afterIn other words, don't be a slaver.ACTUAL REVIEW:Keep in mind I'm viewing this from the prespective of someone who didn't grow up playing these games like many players did, and I actually began on FO3 before trying out the originals. As you can already see, this is not anything like Fallout 3, New Vegas, or 4. This is an entirely new game along the same story line, and if you enjoyed the Wasteland series, this is definitely the game for you. It utilizes seriously outdated graphics and controls are iffy, and support with higher-end PCs is minimal. However, it's still possible to play with a few adjustments and soon you'll be leaping through Navarro and experiencing so many pop culture references from the late 90s, your head will spin. In other words, this is a very nice game with a bit of a learning curve at first, but quickly gets easier and doesn't contain the short timelimit Fallout 1 did. This time, the timelimit is about 13 in-game years, which, even if you explore every inch of the map, do every sidequest, and find every special encounter, you should only be about 2-3 years in, allowing for lots of fun leveling afterwards.

content:
ry 20, 2014
												(Note: Bought this game elsewhere, but wanted a digital version)The sequal to the fantastic Fallout game, you know you are in good hands. This game is set years after the first where you play as a decendent of the Vault Dweller who has been tasked to go out and find the vault for it may contain a G.E.C.K (Garden of Eden Creation Kit) which could save your people as many are sick and dying as are there Brahman. You start by proving your worth by entering the temple of the vault dweller and retriving the vault 13 suit left by your ancestor before heading out for the elusive Vault 13.This game is far better than the previous by doing away with the timer that was in the first one, however the start does involve you running into giant ants and lesser radscorpions in the temple and being armed with only a spear so if you focus on gunpower, there's a good chance you might die or be unable to get through the temple. This game also has the introduction to power gloves if you wish to make a mellee focused character where no previous such weapon exsisted in the first and you were stuck otherwise. There is more adult subject matter as you get to sleep with numerous women (or men depending on sex or your choice) with only a brief description which is somehow more graphic than the Bethesda attempt (dissapointing since the game is a 18, you'd think you'd be treated as a adult) but that's a different discussion for something else.For those who have played Fallout 3, this game is where the Enclave first appeared and in this you run into references to the previous game (appearance of Harold, a discovery of a horde of water chips and a Super mutant who is worried about getting a woman pregnant) as well as an evolution in the society where no longer do people collect bottle caps, but crudly made discs called Dollars.  Ghouls and Super Mutants are no longer a big enemy as they have been trying to intergrate with society (except for Vault City which is Xenophobic) and even gain a Super Mutant as a companion as well as many other interesting and even hidden companions.Well worth if you enjoyed the first game and a lot of fun if you like RPGs in general. You don't need to have played the first one as you can always ask questions about why the world is the way it is and the story has a totally different enemy than the last one. You also have multiple possible endings when you complete the game like the previous one and get to see how Shady Sands has evolved into the infamous NCR.
